title: Introduction to summarytabl
text: package three types functions help summarize data. : Categorical data, binary (e.g., Unselected/Selected) nominal (e.g., woman/man/non-binary) variables Multiple response data, including binary (e.g., Unselected/Selected), multiple-response (e.g., never, sometimes, often), ordinal-scale (e.g., strongly disagree strongly agree) variables Continuous data, like interval (e.g., test scores) ratio-level (e.g., age) variables Functions categorical data start cat_, multiple response data start select_, functions continuous data start mean_. learn functions work, read next sections.

title: Introduction to summarytabl
text: cat_tbl() function can used generate frequency table categorical variable. can exclude certain values eliminate missing values data using ignore na.rm arguments, respectively. Finally, can choose information return using argument.
code: cat_tbl(data = nlsy, var = "race")  ## # A tibble: 3 × 3 ##   race                   count percent ##   <chr>                  <int>   <dbl> ## 1 Black                    868   0.292 ## 2 Hispanic                 631   0.212 ## 3 Non-Black,Non-Hispanic  1477   0.496 cat_tbl(data = nlsy,          var = "race",         ignore = "Black",         na.rm = TRUE)  ## # A tibble: 2 × 3 ##   race                   count percent ##   <chr>                  <int>   <dbl> ## 1 Hispanic                 631   0.299 ## 2 Non-Black,Non-Hispanic  1477   0.701 # Default: counts and percentages cat_group_tbl(data = nlsy,               row_var = "race",               col_var = "bthwht",               na.rm.row_var = TRUE)  ## # A tibble: 6 × 4 ##   race                   bthwht count percent ##   <chr>                   <dbl> <int>   <dbl> ## 1 Black                       0   766   0.279 ## 2 Hispanic                    0   589   0.214 ## 3 Non-Black,Non-Hispanic      0  1394   0.507 ## 4 Black                       1   102   0.449 ## 5 Hispanic                    1    42   0.185 ## 6 Non-Black,Non-Hispanic      1    83   0.366  # Counts only cat_tbl(data = nlsy,          var = "race",         ignore = "Black",         na.rm = TRUE,         only = "count")  ## # A tibble: 2 × 2 ##   race                   count ##   <chr>                  <int> ## 1 Hispanic                 631 ## 2 Non-Black,Non-Hispanic  1477  # Percents only cat_group_tbl(data = nlsy,               row_var = "race",               col_var = "bthwht",               na.rm.row_var = TRUE,               only = "percent")  ## # A tibble: 6 × 3 ##   race                   bthwht percent ##   <chr>                   <dbl>   <dbl> ## 1 Black                       0   0.279 ## 2 Hispanic                    0   0.214 ## 3 Non-Black,Non-Hispanic      0   0.507 ## 4 Black                       1   0.449 ## 5 Hispanic                    1   0.185 ## 6 Non-Black,Non-Hispanic      1   0.366

what: Summarize a categorical variable grouped by another variable
title: Introduction to summarytabl
text: create grouped frequency table two categorical variables, use cat_group_tbl() function. Like cat_tbl(), option exclude certain values omit missing values (row /column). want ignore one value per row column, provide named list: Finally, can choose information return using argument.
code: cat_group_tbl(data = nlsy,               row_var = "gender",               col_var = "bthwht")  ## # A tibble: 4 × 4 ##   gender bthwht count percent ##    <dbl>  <dbl> <int>   <dbl> ## 1      0      0  1340   0.487 ## 2      1      0  1409   0.513 ## 3      0      1   123   0.542 ## 4      1      1   104   0.458 cat_group_tbl(data = nlsy,               row_var = "race",               col_var = "bthwht",               na.rm.row_var = TRUE,               ignore = c(race = "Non-Black,Non-Hispanic"),               pivot = "wider")  ## # A tibble: 2 × 5 ##   race     count_bthwht_0 count_bthwht_1 percent_bthwht_0 percent_bthwht_1 ##   <chr>             <int>          <int>            <dbl>            <dbl> ## 1 Black               766            102            0.565            0.708 ## 2 Hispanic            589             42            0.435            0.292 cat_group_tbl(data = nlsy,               row_var = "race",               col_var = "bthwht",               na.rm.row_var = TRUE,               ignore = list(race = c("Non-Black,Non-Hispanic", "Hispanic")),               pivot = "wider")  ## # A tibble: 1 × 5 ##   race  count_bthwht_0 count_bthwht_1 percent_bthwht_0 percent_bthwht_1 ##   <chr>          <int>          <int>            <dbl>            <dbl> ## 1 Black            766            102                1                1 # Default: counts and percentages cat_group_tbl(data = nlsy,               row_var = "race",               col_var = "bthwht",               na.rm.row_var = TRUE)  ## # A tibble: 6 × 4 ##   race                   bthwht count percent ##   <chr>                   <dbl> <int>   <dbl> ## 1 Black                       0   766   0.279 ## 2 Hispanic                    0   589   0.214 ## 3 Non-Black,Non-Hispanic      0  1394   0.507 ## 4 Black                       1   102   0.449 ## 5 Hispanic                    1    42   0.185 ## 6 Non-Black,Non-Hispanic      1    83   0.366  # Counts only cat_group_tbl(data = nlsy,               row_var = "race",               col_var = "bthwht",               na.rm.row_var = TRUE,               only = "count")  ## # A tibble: 6 × 3 ##   race                   bthwht count ##   <chr>                   <dbl> <int> ## 1 Black                       0   766 ## 2 Hispanic                    0   589 ## 3 Non-Black,Non-Hispanic      0  1394 ## 4 Black                       1   102 ## 5 Hispanic                    1    42 ## 6 Non-Black,Non-Hispanic      1    83  # Percents only cat_group_tbl(data = nlsy,               row_var = "race",               col_var = "bthwht",               na.rm.row_var = TRUE,               only = "percent")  ## # A tibble: 6 × 3 ##   race                   bthwht percent ##   <chr>                   <dbl>   <dbl> ## 1 Black                       0   0.279 ## 2 Hispanic                    0   0.214 ## 3 Non-Black,Non-Hispanic      0   0.507 ## 4 Black                       1   0.449 ## 5 Hispanic                    1   0.185 ## 6 Non-Black,Non-Hispanic      1   0.366

what: Summarize a series of multiple response variables
title: Introduction to summarytabl
text: select_tbl(), can produce summary table multiple response variables variable stem. variable stem common prefix found related variable names, often corresponding similar survey items, represents shared concept unique identifiers. example, depressive dataset contains eight variables share stem, one representing different item (statement, question, indicator) used measure depression: select_tbl() function, can summarize responses see many survey respondents chose answer option every variable: can also use ignore na_removal arguments exclude values data specify missing values handled. default, missing values removed listwise, can set na_removal pairwise pairwise removal instead: Set pivot argument wider reshape resulting table wide format. default, summary table presented long format. can use var_labels argument include variable labels summary table make variable names easier interpret: Finally, can choose information return using argument.
code: names(depressive)  ##  [1] "cid"   "race"  "sex"   "yob"   "dep_1" "dep_2" "dep_3" "dep_4" "dep_5" ## [10] "dep_6" "dep_7" "dep_8" select_tbl(data = depressive, var_stem = "dep")  ## # A tibble: 24 × 4 ##    variable values count percent ##    <chr>     <int> <int>   <dbl> ##  1 dep_1         1   109  0.0678 ##  2 dep_1         2   689  0.429  ##  3 dep_1         3   809  0.503  ##  4 dep_2         1   144  0.0896 ##  5 dep_2         2   746  0.464  ##  6 dep_2         3   717  0.446  ##  7 dep_3         1  1162  0.723  ##  8 dep_3         2   392  0.244  ##  9 dep_3         3    53  0.0330 ## 10 dep_4         1   601  0.374  ## # ℹ 14 more rows # Default listwise removal, value '3' removed from data select_tbl(data = depressive,             var_stem = "dep",             ignore = 3)  ## # A tibble: 16 × 4 ##    variable values count percent ##    <chr>     <int> <int>   <dbl> ##  1 dep_1         1    37   0.167 ##  2 dep_1         2   185   0.833 ##  3 dep_2         1    47   0.212 ##  4 dep_2         2   175   0.788 ##  5 dep_3         1   133   0.599 ##  6 dep_3         2    89   0.401 ##  7 dep_4         1   108   0.486 ##  8 dep_4         2   114   0.514 ##  9 dep_5         1    61   0.275 ## 10 dep_5         2   161   0.725 ## 11 dep_6         1    86   0.387 ## 12 dep_6         2   136   0.613 ## 13 dep_7         1   126   0.568 ## 14 dep_7         2    96   0.432 ## 15 dep_8         1    81   0.365 ## 16 dep_8         2   141   0.635  # Pairwise removal, value '3' removed from data select_tbl(data = depressive,             var_stem = "dep",             ignore = 3,            na_removal = "pairwise")  ##  4 dep_2         2   762   0.835 ##  5 dep_3         1  1192   0.746 ##  6 dep_3         2   406   0.254 ##  7 dep_4         1   611   0.416 ##  8 dep_4         2   856   0.584 ##  9 dep_5         1   206   0.264 ## 10 dep_5         2   574   0.736 ## 11 dep_6         1   399   0.312 ## 12 dep_6         2   879   0.688 ## 13 dep_7         1  1046   0.674 ## 14 dep_7         2   507   0.326 ## 15 dep_8         1   323   0.287 ## 16 dep_8         2   801   0.713 # Default longer format select_tbl(data = depressive,             var_stem = "dep")  ## # A tibble: 24 × 4 ##    variable values count percent ##    <chr>     <int> <int>   <dbl> ##  1 dep_1         1   109  0.0678 ##  2 dep_1         2   689  0.429  ##  3 dep_1         3   809  0.503  ##  4 dep_2         1   144  0.0896 ##  5 dep_2         2   746  0.464  ##  6 dep_2         3   717  0.446  ##  7 dep_3         1  1162  0.723  ##  8 dep_3         2   392  0.244  ##  9 dep_3         3    53  0.0330 ## 10 dep_4         1   601  0.374  ## # ℹ 14 more rows  # Wider format select_tbl(data = depressive,             var_stem = "dep",            pivot = "wider")  ## # A tibble: 8 × 7 ##   variable count_value_1 count_value_2 count_value_3 percent_value_1 ##   <chr>            <int>         <int>         <int>           <dbl> ## 1 dep_1              109           689           809          0.0678 ## 2 dep_2              144           746           717          0.0896 ## 3 dep_3             1162           392            53          0.723  ## 4 dep_4              601           836           170          0.374  ## 5 dep_5              194           556           857          0.121  ## 6 dep_6              387           860           360          0.241  ## 7 dep_7             1028           490            89          0.640  ## 8 dep_8              317           784           506          0.197  ## # ℹ 2 more variables: percent_value_2 <dbl>, percent_value_3 <dbl> select_tbl(data = depressive,             var_stem = "dep",            pivot = "wider",            var_labels = c(              dep_1="how often child feels sad and blue",              dep_2="how often child feels nervous, tense, or on edge",              dep_3="how often child feels happy",              dep_4="how often child feels bored",              dep_5="how often child feels lonely",              dep_6="how often child feels tired or worn out",              dep_7="how often child feels excited about something",              dep_8="how often child feels too busy to get everything"            ) )  ## what: Summarize a series of multiple response variables grouped by a variable or matching pattern
title: Introduction to summarytabl
text: select_group_tbl(), can create summary table multiple response variables variable stem, grouped either another variable dataset matching pattern variable names. example, often want summarize survey responses demographic variables like gender, age, race: cat_group_tbl(), can specify values exclude remove missing values. However, specifying values exclude, use var_stem argument provide determine values exclude variables sharing stem. Use list want exclude several values var_stem group variable: Another application select_group_tbl summarizing responses based matching pattern, survey time points (e.g., waves). use feature, set group_type pattern enter pattern search group argument. example, stem_social_psych dataset includes set variables responded students two different time points (“w1” “w2”). can summarize responses one set variables using following approach: Use group_name argument assign descriptive name column containing matched pattern values. can use var_labels argument include variable labels summary table make variable names easier interpret: Finally, can choose information return using argument.
code: dep_recoded <-    depressive |>   dplyr::mutate(     race = dplyr::case_match(.x = race,                              1 ~ "Hispanic",                               2 ~ "Black",                               3 ~ "Non-Black/Non-Hispanic",                              .default = NA)   ) |>   dplyr::mutate(     dplyr::across(       .cols = dplyr::starts_with("dep"),       .fns = ~ dplyr::case_when(.x == 1 ~ "often",                                  .x == 2 ~ "sometimes",                                  .x == 3 ~ "hardly ever")     )   )  # longer format select_group_tbl(data = dep_recoded,                   var_stem = "dep",                  group = "race",                  pivot = "longer")  ## # A tibble: 72 × 5 ##    variable race                   values      count percent ##    <chr>    <chr>                  <chr>       <int>   <dbl> ##  1 dep_1    Black                  hardly ever   248   0.307 ##  2 dep_1    Hispanic               hardly ever   187   0.231 ##  3 dep_1    Non-Black/Non-Hispanic hardly ever   374   0.462 ##  4 dep_1    Black                  often          45   0.413 ##  5 dep_1    Hispanic               often          28   0.257 ##  6 dep_1    Non-Black/Non-Hispanic often          36   0.330 ##  7 dep_1    Black                  sometimes     194   0.282 ##  8 dep_1    Hispanic               sometimes     155   0.225 ##  9 dep_1    Non-Black/Non-Hispanic sometimes     340   0.493 ## 10 dep_2    Black                  hardly ever   234   0.326 ## # ℹ 62 more rows  # wider format select_group_tbl(data = dep_recoded,                   var_stem = "dep",                  group = "race",                  pivot = "wider")  ## # A tibble: 24 × 8 ##    variable race                   count_value_hardly eve…¹ count_value_often ##    <chr>    <chr>                                     <int>             <int> ##  1 dep_1    Black                                       248                45 ## what: Summarize a series of continuous variables
title: Introduction to summarytabl
text: mean_tbl() function, can summarize group continuous variables share variable stem. resulting table provides descriptive statistics variable, including mean, standard deviation, minimum, maximum, number non-missing values. Like functions package, can use ignore argument specify values exclude variables associated provided variable stem. can also specify missing values removed: Including variable labels summary table can help make variable names easier interpret. Finally, can choose information return using argument.
code: mean_tbl(data = social_psy_data,           var_stem = "belong")  ## # A tibble: 3 × 6 ##   variable  mean    sd   min   max  nobs ##   <chr>    <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <int> ## 1 belong_1  3.83 1.10      1     5 10105 ## 2 belong_2  2.52 1.22      1     5 10105 ## 3 belong_3  3.77 0.995     1     5 10105 mean_tbl(data = social_psy_data,           var_stem = "belong",          ignore = 5)  ## # A tibble: 3 × 6 ##   variable  mean    sd   min   max  nobs ##   <chr>    <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <int> ## 1 belong_1  3.31 0.827     1     4  5752 ## 2 belong_2  2.85 0.970     1     4  5752 ## 3 belong_3  3.38 0.754     1     4  5752 # Default listwise removal mean_tbl(data = social_psy_data,           var_stem = "belong",          ignore = 5)  ## # A tibble: 3 × 7 ##   variable variable_label                        mean    sd   min   max  nobs ##   <chr>    <chr>                                <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <int> ## 1 belong_1 I feel like I belong at this instit…  3.83 1.10      1     5 10138 ## what: Summarize a series of continuous variables grouped by a variable or matching pattern
title: Introduction to summarytabl
text: mean_group_tbl() function, can produce summary table series continuous variables sharing variable stem, grouped another variable dataset matching pattern variable names. example, often want present summary statistics responses demographic variables like gender, age, race: select_group_tbl(), can specify values exclude whether omit missing values. sure use var_stem argument provide determine values exclude variables sharing stem. Use list want exclude several values var_stem group variable: Another application mean_group_tbl summarizing responses based matching pattern, survey time points (e.g., waves). use feature, set group_type pattern enter pattern search group argument. what: Summarize a categorical variable by a grouping variable — cat_group_tbl
title: Summarize a categorical variable by a grouping variable — cat_group_tbl
text: cat_group_tbl() presents frequency counts percentages (count, percent) nominal categorical variables grouping variable. Relative frequencies percentages level primary categorical variable (row_var) within level grouping variable (col_var) can returned. Missing data can excluded either variable calculations. default, table returned long format.

text: data data frame. row_var character string name column data containing categorical data. primary categorical variable. pivoted wider format, categories variable appear rows table. col_var character string name column data containing categorical data. primary categorical variable. pivoted wider format, categories variable appear rows table. na.rm.row_var logical value indicating whether missing values row_var removed calculations. Default FALSE. character string vector strings indicating types summary data return. default NULL, includes counts percentages. return one type, specify count percent. text: mean_group_tbl() presents descriptive statistics (mean, sd, minimum, maximum, number non-missing observations) interval (e.g., Test scores) ratio level (e.g., Age) variables variable stem grouping variable. variable stem common prefix found related variable names, often corresponding similar survey items, represents shared concept unique identifiers (like time points) added. example, stem_social_psych dataset, two variables 'belong_belongStem_w1' 'belong_belongStem_w2' share variable stem 'belong_belongStem' (e.g., "feel like outsider STEM"), suffixes (_w1, _w2) indicating different measurement waves. default, missing data excluded calculations listwise fashion.

Default FALSE. group_type character string defines type grouping variable. one pattern variable. Default variable, case variable matching group string searched within data. group_name character string piped final table replace name group. escape_group logical value indicating whether escape string supplied group. ignore_group_case logical value indicating whether group case-insensitive. Default FALSE. remove_group_non_alnum logical value indicating whether remove non- alphanumeric characters (anything letter number) group. Default TRUE. na_removal character string specifying remove missing values. one pairwise listwise. Default listwise. character string vector character strings types summary data return. Default NULL, returns mean (mean), standard deviation (sd), minimum value (min), maximum value (max), non-missing responses (nobs). var_labels optional named character vector list element maps labels variable names. element unnamed labels match variables returned data, labels ignored table printed without . ignore optional named vector list specifying values exclude dataset analysis. default, NULL includes available values. omit values variables returned var_stem, use provided stem name. exclude values var_stem variables grouping variable data, supply list.
